To beckon or not to beckon: Testing a causal-evaluative modelling approach to moral judgment: A registered report

morality
moral judgment
categorization
dual-processes
moral dumbfounding
Journal of Experimental Social Psychology (2024)
Authors
Affiliations

Cillian McHugh

Department of Psychology, University of Limerick Ireland

Kathryn B. Francis

School of Psychology, Faculty of Natural Sciences, Keele University, UK

Jim A. C. Everett

School of Psychology, Keynes College, University of Kent, UK

Shane Timmons

Economic & Social Research Institute, Ireland

Published

April 3, 2024

Moral judgments are increasingly being understood as showing context dependent variability. A growing literature has identified a range of specific contextual factors (e.g., emotions, intentions) that can influence moral judgments in predictable ways. Integrating these diverse influences into a unified approach to understanding moral judgments remains a challenge. Recent work by Railton (2017) attempted to address this with a causal-evaluative modelling approach to moral judgment. In support of this model Railton presents evidence from novel variations of classic trolley type dilemmas. We present results from a pre-registered pilot study that highlight a significant confound and demonstrate that it likely influenced Railtonâ€™s results. Building on this, our registered report presents a replication-extension of Railtonâ€™s study, using larger more diverse samples, and more rigorous methods and materials, specifically controlling for potential confounds. We found that participantsâ€™ judgments in sacrificial dilemmas are influenced by both direct personal force, and by whether harm occurs as a means or as a side-effect of action. We also show the relationship between a range of individual difference variables and responses to sacrificial moral dilemmas. Our results provide novel insights into the factors that influence peopleâ€™s moral judgments, and contribute to ongoing theoretical debates in moral psychology.

Bibliography
McHugh, C., Francis, K. B., Everett, J. A. C., & Timmons, S. (2024). To beckon or not to beckon: Testing a causal-evaluative modelling approach to moral judgment: A registered report. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, 113(C).
